div3.p: Having received authority from the Secretary of War to raise an independent battalion of Light Infantry, to be used exclusively as skirmishers and scouts, and to be attached to no other corps, except at the discretion of the Commander-in-Chief of the department in which we may be stationed, in times of great emergency, I call for volunteers from my own and other States--men now in service, or who have not yet enlisted — to come forward at this critical juncture, when the primal glory of our arms is partially eclipsed in a temporary gloom, and enroll their names in a corps which will come frequently in contact with the polluters of our soil and the desolator of our homes.

I propose to facilitate the organization of the battalion by offering Captaincies to those enlisting not less than thirty men, 1st Lieutenancies to those enlisting twenty-five, 2nd do. to those enlisting twenty.
Seventy privates will be the minimum for a company.
The usual bounty will, of course, be paid, and subsistence and transportation furnished.
For particulars, address me at Yorktown, or W. H. Scott, Druggist, Richmond, Va.

I am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise an Infantry Company, and as no more new companies will be accepted until Virginia's quota has been furnished, this company will be counted as a part of it,) this is one of the few last chances to escape the draft; and who would be drafted?
Men accepted from all parts of the State or Confederacy.
Twelve months men can re-enlist with me, $50 bounty paid as soon as inspected.
Recruiting office at the office of the Insurance Company of the State of Virginia, under the American Hotel, Richmond, Va., Address me,

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mail to

div3.head: Attention.
div3.p:
--The organization of our company is now nearly completed.
We have the guns secured and all equipments ready as soon as we are mustered into service.
Those who do not immediately volunteer will be obliged to go into the militia service.
The system of substitution has been abandoned by the Government, so that all who are bound for service must now represent themselves in person.
This we announce upon authority.
We then earnestly invoke those who are willing to share with us the fortunes of this war, who would rather appear voluntarily upon the field in defence of their country than be the reluctant soldiers of coercion, to come forward now, this day, and enlist their names as volunteers in a great and glorious cause.
Apply at our office in the Whig Building.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120.
An opportunity is thus offered to young men, of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service.

Apply to R. B. Pleasants or Henry S. Jones, No. 7, Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr., Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, or Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.

div3.head:
Fifty Dollars bounty.
attention, Volunteers!
Stationary Battery. Heavy Artillery.
div3.p: Lieut. J. Hatley Norton, of the Naval Battery during the past year, having been duty authorized by the Secretary of War, with the approbation and approval of Major-General Magruder, to raise and organize a company of 125 men, for the Yorktown Naval Battery, hereby offers an opportunity to healthy, able-bodied, courageous men, to enlist in the cause of their country, and in one of the best locations in the Southern States.

This celebrated Battery is now completed, and the prospects of a speedy advance of the enemy to this point at the opening of the Spring campaign, renders it necessary that this company should be filled up at as early a day as possible and should also be an inducement to all those having their country's interest at heart, to hasten to her aid and to be found at a post where they can reader her the most efficient service.
As soon as the exigencies of the case will permit, furloughs to all re-enlisted men will be granted regularly, and a certain number may be absent from the company at stated times.
div3.closer:
Apply to Lieut. Norton
At Duval's Drug Store, Richmond, or at the Naval Battery, Yorktown. mh 19--6*

Attention!
Teamsters.
div3.p:
I wish to enlist ten or twelve good Drivers for my battery.
To experienced men I will give $25, in addition to the Government bounty of $50. Persons wishing to emit will please call on me without delay, at Camp Lee, near this city.

Twenty men wanted to complete the organization.
$50 bounty.

div3.head:
Headqr's Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 15, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 8.

I. The practice of fast driving and riding through the city endangers the safety of the people, and is, therefore, prohibited.
The speed for omnibuses, light carriages, and horseback riding, is at the rate of five miles per hour; wagons, carts, and other vehicles for freight, will be driven at a walk, whether loaded or unloaded.
The police and patrol are charged with the execution of this order, and will arrest every one who may violate it, no matter what his rank or position.
If the driver or rider be a white man, he will be confined and brought before a court-martial; if a negro, he will immediately receive, for the first offence, 89 lashes; for the second and every succeeding offence, 50 lashes.

div3.head: Heavy Artillery.
div3.p:
$50 Bounty,
and Uniforms furnished.

The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.head:
Headquarters Department of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 17, 1862.
div3.p: General order, No. 9.--

III.
Conductors and Engineers of railroad trains, and persons having charge of Canal Boats, who permit any one to leave this city on their trains or boats without passports, will be arrested and brought to trial before a Court-Martial.

div3.head: Recruits wanted for an Infirmary Company.
div3.p:
--Having obtained from the Secretary of War authority to organize an Infirmary Company, to go into the active service of the Confederate States for the war, I respectfully call upon all persons subject to militia duty to enlist in this new branch of the service.
This company's duties will be to attend the wounded soldiers on a field of battle, and to prevent them from bleeding to death.
The company will be stationed a short distance in the rear of the line of battle, to immediately dress the wounds of each soldier wounded and remove him from the field to some proper hospital.
Each man enlisting will receive the bounty of $50. Uniforms and equipments also furnished.
Having nearly my complement of men, I should like to receive about 30 more good recruits.
Apply soon at my recruiting office, Broad street, between 6th and 7th streets.

div3.head:
Attention!
Sturdivant's Battery.
div3.p: We can still accept twenty-five Recruits.--Apply at Darracott, Harris & Co.'s, No. 112 Main street, or the Rendezvous, corner of Bank and 11th streets.
Members who have not reported will do so at once.

div3.head: Militia, attention.
div3.p: --I am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery, to be attached to Morrisa's Battalion.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid when the roll is signed and the volunteer sworn in.
Call at P. H. Starke's, Main, between 14th and 15th streets, for the present.
Any militia man can come in, sign the roll, take the bounty, and be attempt.

Executive Department,
Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862.
div3.p:
all Sheriffs and others collecting State Arms are desired to have the same boxed, marked "Col. C. Dimmock, Richmond, Va.," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting, and the necessary expenses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adj't and Insp'r Gen.'s office,
Richmond, March 14, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 15:
I. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
Proclamation.

By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus, J. Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that Martial Law is hereby extended over the counties of Elizabeth City, James City, York, Warwick, Gloucester, and Mathews; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualifications of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties a foresaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal, this fourteenth day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
Jefferson Davis.

II. Major-General Magruder, commanding the Army of the Peninsula, is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation.
He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:

All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial; provided, that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper.
Adj't and Insp. General. mh 15--1w

Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Capt. Wm. W. Parker's Company of Light Artillery having been mustered into service and secured a battery of six guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits, if they are of the right sort.
Apply at his office, in the Law Building, at once.

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers.
div3.p: --It will be seen by the following proclamation that persons who prefer to volunteer rather than be subjected to the discredit of the militia draft, can do so by coming forward now and declaring their willingness to serve their country of their own accord:

div4.head:
Executive Department, Va.,
March 11th, 1862.
div4.p:
The commandants of companies of volunteers, authorized to be raised by the Governor, which are not yet completed are hereby permitted to fill up their commands by volunteers from the militia of the State until the militia are mustered into service.
No substitutes will be allowed.
div4.closer:
By order of the Governor.
S. Bassett French,
Aide-de-camp.

div4.p:
It will thus be seen that the alternative presented now is, whether Virginians will volunteer to defend the Southern cause, or be subjected into service by force.
As will be seen, this choice must be made at once.
Will not the sons of Virginia now come forward and enlist their names.--Apply at our office, in the Whig Building.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--The Infantry Company organized at the office of Dr. Parker, in the Law Building, having received assurance of a "Battery of Light Artillery," it was unanimously resolved, at a meeting held last Saturday night, to adopt that arm of the service.
The guns will be ready in less thirty days. So soon as the company is fully organized it will go into the Camp of Instruction at the Fair Grounds.
All those disposed to join will report as early as possible, at Dr. Parker's office, as the company expects to be mustered in this week.
Meetings held regularly on Wednesday and Saturday nights.

div3.head: Attention!
div3.p:
The undersigned propose to raise a company of Light Artillery to be enlisted for the war. We are happy now to announce that we have procured the guns, which will be ready for us, together with all equipments, as soon as our company is mustered into service.
To those who would like to go along with us and share with us the fortunes of this war, we earnestly appeal to come forward now and join us at office.
Besides the bounty of $50, uniforms, board and lodgings will be furnished free.
Application may be made at our Recruiting office, on Main, between 7th and 8th streets, or at the store of Johnston & Branford.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Elliott Grays,
Fort Nelson, Norfolk Harbor,
March --, 1862.
div3.p:
this well-known company having determined to remain in the service, is desirous of increasing the number of enlisted men to 125.
A Recruiting Office has been opened for that purpose at the store of Louis J. Bossieux, 80 Main street, and also at the store of Joseph Butler, town of Manchester.
All young men who are disposed to volunteer can learn the particulars of the condition and organization of the company from Lieut. Henry Fitzgerald, who can be found at either place of rendezvous.
Recruits are entitled to pay, transportation, and subsistence, from the time and place of enrollment, and also to the bounty of fifty dollars.

I hope that this call may meet with a speedy, response, and that I may never be a witness to the drafting of young men from the districts in the neighborhood of Richmond.
All recruits are to be persons of good character, and men in whom I can place implicit confidence.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--The present condition of our country seems to us to require the services of all who are capable of bearing arms and in a situation to leave home.
We have therefore obtained from the Secretary of War authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, and call upon our fellow- citizens to come forward and aid us in getting it up.

We want, if possible to raise a company sufficient to man a battery of six guns, and think this enterprise offers a fine opportunity to all who wish to volunteer, and thus save themselves from a draft in the militia.
Gray uniform, of the Crenshaw Woolen Company Goods, will be furnished free, and the bounty of $50 paid to each man when the company is mustered in.
Rendezvous at the warehouse on the Basin bank, next door to Crenshaw & Co.'s, where one of the undersigned may always be found, and recruits maintained free of all expense.
The traveling expenses of recruits from the country to the city will be paid.

div3.head:
Recruits.--
Richmond Sharp Shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well-known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange, Bank street, or to Corporal W. J. Wingfield.

div3.head: Attention, young men of Richmond.
div3.p: Having been detailed to recruit for the First Regiment Virginia Volunteers, (now stationed at Centreville,) a bounty of Fifty Dollars, uniform and subsistence, will be given to all able-bodied young men who may enlist in this, the oldest volunteer regiment in the Confederate States.
For further particulars apply at the recruiting station, No. 3, 10th street, between Main and Cary streets.
div3.closer:
W. W. Harrison,
Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer.
P. S.--Two new companies will be received, as there are at present but eight in the
regiment. [mh 8--ts] W. W. H.

div3.head: Naval, Medical board of examination.
div3.p: --A Board of Naval Surgeons is in session in in this city, by order of the Navy Department, for the examination of candidates for admission in the naval service of the Confederate States as assistant surgeons during the war.
The age of the candidate must not be less than twenty-one nor more than thirty years.

--Two likely young man. One is an accomplished Water, as well as Cook and Driver.

div3.head: Ranaway.--$20 reward.
div3.p:
--From my farm, in Powhatan county, about the 1st of February, my Negro man, George, aged about 23 years. George is dark complexioned; good teeth; large eyes, and shuffles when walking.
Has been lurking about the premises of Benj. Gray, Esq, on Franklin street, where he has an aunt; has also a sister near the gas works.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery at Robert Lumpkin's jail, in this city.

div3.head: $5 reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay five dollars for the arrest of my negro man Otterway.
He calls himself Brock, and is well known in Rocketts' old field.

div3.head: Ranaway--$10 reward.
div3.p:
--From my residence, on 20th street, about the first of March, a Negro Woman, named Jane, sometimes called Eliza.
The said negro is about 25 years old, dark complexion, and has a small scar on her eyebrow.
Was hired from Banks Wade, near Rocketts.
I will pay the above reward for her return.

div3.head: Runaway--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Left without provocation, about 1st January last, my boy Henry, about 26 years of age, a barber by trade, hired for the present year to Wermer & Co., opposite the American Hotel.
Henry is a spare, brown colored boy, about 5½ feet high, genteel address, wears a small beard, with full head of hair.
He may have hired himself to go with some officer or soldier.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me or Mr. Wermer, or any information of his whereabouts, so that I get him.

div3.head: Runaway.
div3.p:
--A negro boy by the name of Floyd, had been staying with his young master at Evansport, and was taken sick and started home with a man by the name of Dr. H. E. Herst, and the train left him at Burksville, Va. The said boy is about 35 years of age, dark complexion, about 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high.
His general weight is about 150 pound heavy person taking up the said boy, will have him confined in some safe jail, and I will pay all charges for his delivery to me.
div3.closer:
J. W. Alsobrooks,
Mill Town, Alabama. fe 17--1m*
